pullRequest.title: SS7 upgrade: required amendments to samples
pullRequest.bodyText:
Description
See cs issue 2274.
This PR makes the required changes for an upgrade of SS7.

Edit with branch versioning - amended service URL and amended existing credentials
Configure subnetwork trace - amended service URL and added in credentials
Display utility associations - amended service URL and added in credentials
Perform valve isolation trace - amended service URL and added in credentials
Trace a utility network - amended service URL and added in credentials
Display subtype feature layer - amended service URL and added in credentials
Trace a utility network - amended feature table setup and added in credentials

@sclaridge and I have tested the samples (note: have to follow instructions in cs issue 2270 to update hosts file until the upgraded server is live)
@JonLavi @TADraeseke  please could you review so that this PR is ready to be merged whenever they flick the switch on the new server. Thanks!

Checklist:

 Set target branch to master (current release) or dev (next release)
 Request a reviewer
 Assign a reviewer
 Tag reviewer in comment

commit.message: Edit with branch versioning - update Controller and README
Configure subnetwork trace: update service URL and add authentication
Display utility assocations - update service URL and authentication
Perform valve isolation trace - update service URL and authentication
Trace a utility network - update service URL and authentication
Display subtype feature layer - update service URL and authentication
Trace a utility network - amend feature tables

nodes.bodyText: This looks like quite a 'serious' password (as opposed to the previous one), are we sure it's supposed to be public? I'm confident this didn't get put out by mistake, but best to make triple sure?
Could we put this on one line instead?

Same question about this PW - it looks quite realistic, so not sure if it's supposed to be here? If the PW is public, then there's no need in creating a 'secure' password, viewer01.password would work just as well and would be memorable if a user tries to play with authentication forms?
There's possibly a few more cases like this in the remainder of the files, so I won't comment on those
